journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit

title-group.article-title: Train induced ground vibrations: different amplitude-speed relations for two layered soils

article-meta.aff: BAM Federal Institute for Materials Research and Testing, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Lutz Auersch, BAM Federal Institute for Materials Research and Testing, 12200 Berlin, Germany. Email: lutz.auersch-saworski@bam.de

abstract.p: Ground vibrations created by running high-speed trains at speeds between 100 and 320 km/h are calculated in detail using transfer functions to model the effects of the moving loads. These transfer functions for layered soils are obtained by integration in the wavenumber domain. The train-induced vibrations in a soil that is considered to consist of single layers of two slightly different soils are analysed for different excitations: for their spectra, attenuation laws and amplitude–speed relations. An important mid-frequency component is shifted through the cut-on region of the layered soil with an increase in the train speed. The cut-on frequency divides the response of the layered soil into a low-frequency low-amplitude range and a high-frequency high-amplitude range. This leads to completely different train speed dependencies for the two soil layers with strongly increasing amplitudes around the cut-on frequency and almost constant amplitudes beyond this frequency. All calculated results closely agree with ground vibration measurements at two corresponding sites, especially if the mid-frequency component is calculated by axle impulses.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Dynamic loads and the changes of the static loads on a rail track that are created when trains pass over the track generate waves through the underlying soil that result in complex ground vibration behaviour. In general, it is expected that the ground vibration amplitudes increase with increasing train speed. However, there is no general rule for the amplitude–speed relation, which can be of importance in the planning of high-speed traffic or in the prediction of the benefit of a speed reduction. The possible strong increase in the ground vibration due to a sonic boom or due to inertial forces should be contrasted with moderate amplitude–speed relations. This article presents a situation, where it was difficult to fix specific rules for a specific train, track and soil, and shows that clear amplitude–speed relations can be established if the layered soils are properly modelled for each site (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Train-induced ground vibrations in two layered soils.

The theoretical methods are based on the calculation of the soil response using the integration in the wavenumber domain, an approach that was introduced by Kausel and Roesset1 and Wolf.2 The specific phenomena are due to the layering of the soil, and a single layer on a stiffer half-space is considered in this paper. This soil model and the corresponding effects have been previously reported in the literature.3–6 A layer on a half-space has a cut-on or resonance frequency which divides the frequencies into a low-frequency range with low amplitudes and a high-frequency range with high amplitudes. At the cut-on frequency, there is a strong increase in the amplitude which is of fundamental importance for the amplitude–speed relations. The cut-on of high-frequency amplitudes is also called a cut-off of the low-frequency amplitudes. This cut-off has been proposed as a countermeasure for traffic-induced ground vibrations.7–9 A further analysis of this basic layered soil model will be performed in this paper.

For high-speed trains, there exist methods to account for the effects created by moving loads.10–18 These methods have been frequently applied to the case where the train speed and the Rayleigh wave velocity of the soil coincide. In this article, the same methods are used to calculate the effects due to moving loads that occur at subcritical train speeds: namely, the quasi-static component of the train passage and the Doppler effect for a single excitation frequency. In addition to the time-consuming exact formula, simple formula have been derived19 which can be used in a fast and user-friendly software for the prediction of train-induced ground and building vibrations.20 The prediction of train-induced vibrations needs some knowledge of the wheel and track irregularities and the analysis of the vehicle–track interaction. The relations between the dynamic forces and the irregular and regular variations of the wheel and the track are briefly summarised from Auersch21 including the important sleeper-passage excitation. The importance of the dynamic loads has been emphasised in Auersch22 as well as in Sheng.6 A special introduction is given to the dynamic loads of the axle impulses which are only visible if the generated waves are scattered by a randomly varying soil.19,23 This ground vibration component can be clearly distinguished from the component due to track irregularities by analysing the relation between train speed and amplitude.

The relation between the ground vibration amplitude A and the train speed vT has been empirically derived from measured data to have the form of A~νTn. For many amplitude–speed relations, the exponent n has a value near to one, for example, n ≤ 1.1 in Volberg24 and Haupt25, 0.9 ≤ n ≤ 1.1 in Madshus et al.26 and n = 1.0 in Bahrekazemi.27 However, some minor deviations from A ∼ vTn have been reported and the American Federal Transit Administration28 has published a decibel range that corresponds to the exponents from 0.8 to 1.7. Higher exponents, that mean a stronger increase with train speed, have been reported for the Shinkansen trains in Japan. For example, Yoshioka29 reported values of 1.5 to 3.5 whereas Yokoyama et al.30 reported values between 1.2 and 5.6 with the high values being recorded at specific sites that had soft soils; the average values for four railway lines were between 2.2 and 3.4. The different exponents are related to the stiffness and the layering of the soil, and smaller exponents between 1.2 and 2.1 hold for stiff soils as in the present contribution (vS = 250–300 m/s). No general amplitude–speed relation is given in the Handbook of Acoustics,31 however, the amplified amplitudes due to the coincidence of the sleeper-passage excitation and the vehicle–track frequency are pointed out as in Heckl et al.32 A similar sleeper-passage effect was analysed in Auersch. 21,22

This article is based on several measurements that were made at two closely spaced sites in Germany. The speed dependency of the sleeper-passage excitation has been previously obtained and reported in the literature.33 Simulated time histories with single harmonic components with a fixed frequency gave an excellent agreement with the measurements. Other obtained data was evaluated for the mid-frequency narrow-band spectrum which was clearly correlated with the axle-sequence spectrum and shifted with the train speed.21 The measured diverging speed-dependencies of the mid-frequency component of the ground vibrations were discussed in Auersch. 21 The soils close to the track appeared to have the same wave velocity, however, different cut-on frequencies were later reported in Auersch and Maldonado.34 These complex experimental results will now be explained using a detailed modelling of the soil as consisting of different layers.

There is an extensive literature in which comparisons are made between detailed models and measurements.17,19,22,35–39 Many authors, for example, Sheng6 Madshus and Kaynia15 and Takemiya16 compare their models with the measurements of Ledsgard40 performed on trains running faster than the Rayleigh wave of the very soft soil encountered at the measurement site. The complex vehicle–track interaction and possible errors in substructuring are illustrated in Lombaert et al.17 and Kouroussis et al.37 The material damping is an important factor that affects the resulting ground vibration and it is therefore often fitted to get a good correlation with the measurements.35 Maldonado36 obtained high damping values in a detailed experimental analysis. In the last two works, the measurement of the track roughness36 or the wheel forces35 added a new quality to the comparison, but unfortunately the measured response was limited to two measuring points35 or to near-field points.36 Recently, the influence of an embankment and its correct modelling as a beam has been considered.38,39 However, comparisons between theory and measurements are still necessary to establish a better understanding of the ground vibrations, their excitation by the complex vehicle–track interaction and their propagation through the infinite and random soil.

This article is structured as follows. All necessary models and formula are given in the section ‘Methods for railway-induced ground vibration’. First, the model of a layer on a half-space is presented which is solved in the frequency-wavenumber domain. Then, the wavenumber integrals that represent the solutions for fixed or moving loads are given. The following two subsections deal with the vehicle–track interaction and the excitation of ground vibrations by irregularities and by the varying track stiffness values on and between the sleepers (parametric sleeper-distance excitation). The last theoretical subsection describes the excitation by axle impulses. These theoretical methods are applied in the following four results sections. In the section ‘Results: experimental and theoretical transfer functions of two layered soils’ the transfer functions of the two layered soils are presented for a fixed point load and a moving axle load. The section ‘Experimental results for the train-induced ground vibration’ analyses the third-of-an-octave spectra of the near and far-field ground vibrations, which are measured for variation of train speeds between 100 and 300 km/h and for two different measurement sites. In the section ‘Calculated results for the train-induced ground vibration’ the results are compared with calculated ground vibrations of the two layered soil models. The section ‘The relation between the train speed and the ground vibration amplitudes (amplitude–speed relations)’ evaluates the amplitude–speed relations for the two layered soils both for theory and measurement. In the section ‘Discussion of the amplitude–speed relations for the other excitation components, for homogeneous soils and from the literature’ the strong differences between the two layered soils are discussed and compared with the amplitude–speed relations of the other components, with the speed dependency of the total amplitude, the speed dependency for a homogeneous soil and relations from the literature. Finally, conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: Methods and formulas for railway-induced ground vibration
Compliance of the layered soil
sec.p: The soil consists of a horizontal layer with thickness h and an underlying half-space. The layer and the half-space are elastic continua, which are described by their respective material constants: G which is the shear modulus, ν which is Poisson's ratio, ρ which is the density and D which is the damping (G = G0(1 + i2D)). These yield the wave velocities (1)vS=Gρ and vP=2-2ν1-2νvS of the shear and compression wave, respectively.

The compliance of the soil is found in the frequency–wavenumber domain, that is for harmonic waves with wavenumber k and circular frequency ω. The field equation and the interface condition between the layer and the underlying half-space are used to establish the stiffness matrix of the layer-half-space system which relates the horizontal (x) and vertical (z) displacements and stresses of the surface (1) and the layer-half-space interface (2) (2)

The formulas for all the elements Kij of the stiffness matrix of the layer and KijH of the half-space can be found in the literature.1,2,41 The dynamic stiffness matrix K is inverted to the flexibility matrix for which the vertical element of the surface is chosen as the compliance function of the soil in the frequency–wavenumber domain (3)C(k,ω)=K22-1

sec.title: The ground vibration due to fixed and moving loads by integration in the wavenumber domain
sec.p: The ground vibration, the vertical particle velocity v due to a harmonic vertical load F at a distance r (measured from the centre of the load or track to the receiver), is expressed as the transfer admittance function v/F = A(r,ω). This transfer function for a fixed point load is established by the following integration of the compliance transfer function C(k, ω) in the frequency–wavenumber domain5 (4)AP(r,ω)=ω2π∫0∞C(k,ω)J0(kr)kdk where J0 is the Bessel function. The admittance for a fixed rectangle load follows as the double integral18 (5)AR(x,y,ω)=ω(2π)2∫-∞+∞∫-∞+∞C(kx2+ky2,ω) sinc(kxa/2)sinc(kyb/2)exp(ikxx+ikyy) dkxdky This allows the two-dimensional compliance in the wavenumber domain to be integrated to yield a three-dimensional solution.

For the case of a moving load with a circular excitation frequency ωE, the integral can be rewritten as (observing that only points at y = 0 are of interest here) (6) which is a single integration over the wavenumber kx.6 The integrals in equations (4) and (6) are evaluated numerically, see Auersch41 for details.

Equation (4) yields the solution for a single axle load. A sequence of nA axle loads Fi with time delays Ti can be calculated by multiplying the transfer function by the axle-sequence spectrum (7)X(ω)=∑i=1nAFiexp(-jωTi) If the loads of the different wheelsets are uncorrelated, the calculated response of a single axle can be multiplied by the stochastic superposition of all axle loads (8)X2=∑i=1nAFi2 This contribution uses the correlated superposition (equation (7)) of the axle loads except for the wheel irregularities where the uncorrelated superposition (equation (8)) holds.

All results will be presented as third-of-an-octave band spectra between 4 and 160 Hz. The third-of-an-octave band spectra are based on the time interval T = 4 s which was used throughout the measurements. They can be calculated from narrow band spectra or spectral densities (for example, equation (6)) as energetic integrals (9)AT(ωT)=2T∫ω1ω2(AM(ω,ωT))2dω with the frequency limits ω1 = ωT/21/3 and ω2 = ωT 21/3.

sec.title: Vehicle–track interaction and forces due to irregularities
sec.p: The excitation forces due to irregularities are the result of the vehicle–track interaction.21 A train runs on irregular wheels and on an irregular track and the combined reaction of the vehicle and track yields the dynamic loads on the track and the soil. This can be expressed in frequency domain as (10)FVT(ω)=HVT(ω)s(ω)=-KV(ω)KT(ω)KT(ω)+KV(ω)s(ω) where KT (ω) is the dynamic stiffness of the track under an axle load and KV(ω) is the dynamic stiffness (inertia) of the vehicle for a displacement of the axle. The s(ω) are the irregularities of the track and the vehicle (for example out-of-roundness of the wheels) which is usually calculated from the corresponding wavenumber spectra s*(k) or wavelength spectrum s**(λ) as (11)s(ω)=s*(k=ω/v)=s**(λ=2πv/ω) where all spectra are given in third-of-an-octave bands.42

Figures 2(a) and (b) shows irregularity spectra derived from measurements at the same measurement site but in different years.21,42,43 Two main parts can be found in these spectra, a strongly decreasing track alignment component sT at medium frequencies (10–30 Hz) and a weakly decreasing wheel component sW at high frequencies. The irregularity spectra are shifted in frequency when the train speed is increased. Figure 2(b) shows the excitation forces due to these irregularities calculated using equation (10) and the track and vehicle parameters of Table 1. The highest amplitudes are found for the wheel irregularities at the wheel-track resonance at about 100 Hz. The mid-frequency force spectra are nearly constant with a small variation in frequency. The influence of the train speed on the force due to a given alignment error can be clearly followed as a decade increase of the force for an increase of the speed from 100 to 320 km/h which means (12)FT~νT2 in the medium-frequency range below the wheel–track resonance frequency. Figure 2.
(a) Simplified irregularity spectra from measurements21,42,43 and (b) resulting vehicle–track interaction forces, for train speeds vT = ◊ 100, × 125, + 160, Δ 200, ○ 250 and □ 320 km/h. Table 1.
Parameters used in the vehicle–track interaction analysis.
Wheelset mass mW = 1700 kg
UIC 60 rails flexural stiffness EI = 6.4 × 106 Nm2
mass per length m’ = 60 kg/m
Concrete sleepers distance d = 0.6 m
length b = 2.6 m
width a = 0.26 m
height h = 0.2
mass density ρ = 2.5 × 103 kg/m3
modulus of elasticity E = 3 × 1010 N/m2
Poisson's ratio ν = 0.15
Ballast and soil shear modulus GB = 1.5 × 108 N/m2
mass density ρ = 2 × 103 kg/m3
Poisson's ratio ν = 0.33

sec.title: Sleeper-passage excitation – the variation of the track stiffness with the sleeper-passage frequency
sec.p: A special excitation is due to the passage of the train over the regularly varying stiffness of the track on and between the sleepers which is called the sleeper-passage excitation. The sleeper-passage frequency can be written as (13)ωD=2πvTd where d is the sleeper distance and the corresponding force on the track can be calculated as21 (14)

It depends on the stiffness or compliance variation K1/K0 ≈ − C1/C0 of the track and the static load F0 of the train. The value for C1/C0 depends on the stiffness of the soil and ballast and the stiffness of the rail pads and can be found in Auersch.19 Expressed by the displacement variation sD = C1F0 under the static load, the equation becomes similar to equation (10) for the excitation due to irregularities. In this paper, a value of C1 = 0.01 mm/100 kN = 1 × 10−10 m/N or C1/C0 ≈ 5% is used for the rather stiff high-speed track at the measuring site.

sec.title: Excitation by axle impulses
sec.p:
The moving axle loads of the train yield a series of axle impulses on each sleeper and the underlying soil. The spectrum of such an axle impulse has been calculated from the force distribution along the track (the finite-element boundary-element model of the track, see Auersch19) with the parameters of Table 1 and for different train speeds (Figure 3). The axle impulse yields a wide spectrum which is dominant in the mid-frequency range. The higher the train speed, the wider the impulse spectrum. The amplitudes of the impulse spectra vary only weakly with the train speed, and they decrease rather than increase with increasing train speed. Figure 3.
Spectra of the impulse on the soil due to the passage of a 100 kN axle with train speeds vT = ◊ 100, × 125, + 160, Δ 200, ○ 250 and □ 320 km/h, calculated for the track parameters of Table 1.

The results of the axle impulses due to the static loads can be calculated either by a series of locally fixed impulses or by the moving static loads as discussed in the section ‘The ground vibration due to fixed and moving loads by integration in the wavenumber domain’. An additional result of the axle impulses is the scattering of the axle impulses due to randomly varying soil properties; see Auersch19 where an approximate method of calculation and some more experimental details are given. In this contribution, the speed dependency of the axle impulse spectra is used to explain some measured speed dependencies of the ground vibration.

sec.title: Results: Experimental and theoretical transfer functions of two-layer soils
Experimental transfer functions
sec.p:
Measurements of the ground vibrations were performed at two sites near Würzburg, Germany. The properties of the soil were analysed by impulse and vibrator excitation and by the evaluation of the wave velocities and the transfer admittances. A top soil with vR = 270 m/s and an underlying rock of approximately vR ≈ 1000 m/s have been identified (see * and ◊ in Figure 4). The material damping of the soil was determined from the attenuation of the amplitudes with the distance as D ≈ 5%. The measured transfer functions at both sites are presented for different distances (2.5, 5, 10, 20, 30 and 50 m) in Figures 5 and 6 as third-of-an-octave spectra. Theoretical soil models were developed from the measured wave velocities and by modifying the layer thicknesses. Good agreement between measurements and theory was found with the following two soil models. Figure 4.
Frequency-dependent wave velocities of soil models 1 □ and 2 ○, experimental results with vibrator ∗ and hammer ◊ excitation. Figure 5.
Transfer admittance functions measured at site 1, r = □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30, ◊ 40 and ∗ 50 m. Figure 6.
Transfer admittance functions measured at site 2, r = □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m.

sec.title: Theoretical transfer functions (fixed point load)
sec.p: Each of the two soil models consists of a layer with the parameters: vS1 = 270 m/s, ν1 = ν2 = 0.33, ρ1 = ρ2 = 2000 kg/m3, D1 = D2 = 0.05 and an underlying rock with vS2 = 1000 m/s.

Soil model 1 has a layer of depth h1 = 5 m whereas soil model 2 has a layer depth h2 = 10 m (see Figure 1). The theoretical transfer functions of these two soil models are presented in Figures 7 and 8 while the theoretical dispersion curves can be found in Figure 4. Figure 7.
Transfer admittance functions of a thin layer (h = 5 m, vS1 = 270 m/s) on a rock half-space (vS2 = 1000 m/s), amplitudes at □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m distance from the fixed point load. Figure 8.
Transfer admittance functions of a thick layer (h = 10 m, vS1 = 270 m/s) on a rock half-space (vS2 = 1000 m/s), amplitudes at □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m distance from the fixed point load.

Both transfer functions show the same general behaviour, a moderate increase at low frequencies which is followed by a strong increase (‘cut-on’) and constant or even decreasing amplitudes at high frequencies.5 A moderate resonance amplification is closely related with the cut-on. The attenuation with distance is weakest in the mid-frequency resonance region, where only geometrical attenuation is present, and high in the low and high-frequency ranges. The strong high-frequency attenuation is due to the material damping, whereas the low-frequency attenuation is due to the layering of the soil where a large difference between the soft layer near-field amplitudes and the far-field rock amplitudes occurs.

A clear difference between the two soil models can be found for the resonance or cut-on frequency which is at 25 Hz for soil model 1 with the thinner layer and at 12.5 Hz for soil model 2 with the thicker layer. Therefore, soil model 2 has a wider frequency band with high amplitudes which are determined by the softer layer whereas soil model 1 has a wider low-frequency band where the stiffer underlying half-space (the rock) determines the low amplitudes.

sec.title: Transfer functions for a moving distributed load
sec.p:
A similar transfer function for a moving harmonic rectangular load is shown in Figures 9 and 10. For each third-of-an-octave a moving harmonic load is assumed and the resulting spectral densities (equation (6)) are integrated to create third-of-an-octave spectra. The transfer function of the moving load is considerably smaller than that of the fixed load. This is due to the fact that high amplitudes occur only for the short time period taken for the passage of the load. This reduction is stronger for the near-field points. As a consequence, the amplitudes of the different distances are closer together and that means that the attenuation as a function of distance is weaker for the moving load. Thus, the strong attenuation at low and high frequencies is considerably reduced. There is an additional reduction effect at high frequencies due to the distribution of the load across the track. Figure 9.
Transfer admittance functions of a thin layer (h = 5 m, vS1 = 270 m/s) on a rock half-space (vS2 = 1000 m/s), amplitudes at □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m distance from a moving axle load (vT = 200 km/h). Figure 10.
Transfer admittance functions of a thick layer (h = 10 m, vS1 = 270 m/s) on a rock half-space (vS2 = 1000 m/s), amplitudes at □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m distance from a moving axle load (vT = 200 km/h).

sec.title: Experimental results for the train-induced ground vibration
sec.p:
Measurements of the ground vibrations created by high-speed trains have been performed at two sites.43,44 The considered high-speed trains and their axle distances are shown in Figure 11. The following four series of measurements were performed. Figure 11.
The axle-sequence of the three different trains: (a) three-unit train of the first measurement at site 1, (b) five-unit train of the second measurement at site 2 and (c) four-unit train of the third measurement at site 1.

ICE train consisting of the locomotive and two carriages (Figure 11(a)) running at a speed between 100 and 260 km/h. Third-of-an-octave spectra for train speeds of 100, 160, 200 and 250 km/h at distances of x = 2.5, 5, 10, 20, 30 and 50 m are given in Figure 12. Figure 12.
Train-induced ground vibration at site 1, third-of-an-octave spectra at r = □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m measured for the train speeds: (a) 100, (b) 160, (c) 200 and (d) 250 km/h.

ICE train consisting of the locomotive, three carriages and a locomotive (Figure 11(b)) running at a speed between 180 and 300 km/h. Third-of-an-octave spectra for train speeds of 180, 200, 250 and 300 km/h at distances of x = 2.5, 5, 10, 20, 30 and 50 m are given in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Train-induced ground vibration at site 2, third-of-an-octave spectra at r = □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m measured for the train speeds: (a) 180, (b) 200, (c) 250 and (d) 300 km/h.
ICE train consisting of the locomotive, two carriages and a locomotive (Figure 11(c)) running at a speed between 100 and 280 km/h. Third‐of‐an‐octave spectra are given in Auersch.44
ICE train consisting of the locomotive, five carriages and a locomotive Third‐of‐an‐octave spectra are given in Auersch et al.43

The different components can be followed by their characteristic maxima which are shifted with increasing train speed. In addition, the three components are marked by the letters L (low), M (mid) and H (high).

sec.title: Low‐frequency ground vibration due to the passage of static train loads
sec.p: The low‐frequency component of the ground vibration is generally below 10 Hz; however, it gets wider with increasing train speed. It has a maximum which is at 4 to 5 Hz for vT = 160 km/h and at 8 Hz for vT = 300 km/h. The maximum amplitude is at about 0.1 mm/s for the nearest point to the track which is comparable to the amplitudes of the other components of the ground vibration. The amplitudes at other distances from the track are considerably smaller. The attenuation with distance is significantly stronger than the strong low‐frequency attenuation of a layered soil. The strong attenuation is a specific effect of the response to the moving static load.19,21,22

sec.title: High‐frequency ground vibration due to the sleeper‐passage excitation
sec.p: The high‐frequency component of the ground vibration is a narrow frequency band in the spectrum. The centre frequency of this band is strictly increasing with the train speed and can be calculated as the sleeper‐passage frequency fD = vT/d, see Table 2. The width of this frequency band is one or two‐thirds of an octave due to the Doppler effect for moving loads. This component of the train‐induced ground vibration has the highest amplitude of all components in some of the figures. Since the high‐frequency ground vibration is highly reduced by the damping effect due to the soil, the amplitude due to the sleeper‐passage excitation decays rapidly in the far‐field region where they have no importance.

sec.title: Mid‐frequency ground vibration
sec.p: An important component of the train‐induced ground vibration is observed between 10 and 30 Hz. It is the most important component in the far‐field region, and it is also important in the near‐field region where its amplitude is comparable to that of the other ground vibration components. The mid‐frequency component is not easy to identify as it seems to be a mixture of constant and speed‐dependent frequencies.

A weak maximum, a clear minimum below the maximum (approximately at half the frequency) and a weak minimum above the maximum can be found in the third‐of‐an octave spectra, particularly at the near‐field points. These minima and the maximum can be attributed to the axle sequence of the train and they are mainly ruled by the distance between the two axles within a bogie (see Auersch21). These characteristics can be used to identify the mid‐frequency ground vibration component. Typical are the three octaves between the two minima where the amplitudes have high values (Figure 13). No axle‐distance peak appears in the spectrum, and the minima are clearer than the maximum. The axle sequence yields the characteristics of the mid‐frequency ground vibration spectra but it is not an excitation mechanism in itself.

The differences between the two soil models are limited to the mid‐frequency component of the ground vibration. In general, the mid‐frequency amplitudes are higher for soil model 2 with the thick softer layer. Moreover, the maximum amplitudes can be easily recognized since they have almost constant amplitudes and clearly shifted frequencies with increasing train speed from 10 to 16 Hz for 180 km/h to 20 to 32 Hz for 300 km/h. Contrarily, for soil model 1 the amplitudes increase with increasing train speed and the frequencies seem to be constant at about 25 Hz.

sec.title: Calculated results for the train‐induced ground vibration
Ground vibration due to theoretical and experimentally based excitation components
sec.p: The ground vibrations due to high‐speed trains were calculated for both layered soil models. The following types of excitation were considered to be acting simultaneously: moving static loads of F0 = 100 kN for the cars and F0 = 200 kN for the locomotives, the moving sleeper‐passage excitation expressed as sD = 0.012 mm (as theoretical excitation components), and a small part (30%) of the measured irregularities sW of the wheels (Figure 2(a)) which were chosen to avoid zero ground vibration amplitudes at high frequencies. Two alternatives for the mid‐frequency excitation were analysed. Excitation alternative A used the measured track alignment error sT of Figure 2(a), whereas excitation alternative B used the theoretical axle impulse spectra of Figure 3. Both alternatives were calibrated by the measured mid‐frequency amplitudes at site 2 for a train speed of vT = 250 km/h. The calibration used only one factor (it had a value of one for excitation A and one‐fifth for excitation B) for all frequencies and distances, for all train speeds and both sites.

The ground vibrations for site 2 are shown in Figure 14 (alternative A) (please refer to Figure 16(e) for the data for alternative B). The third‐of‐an‐octave spectra look very similar to the measured spectra in Figure 13(c), they have the same mid‐frequency characteristics, and the amplitudes for 250 km/h are almost the same. Figure 14.
Train-induced ground vibration on soil 2 (thick layer), third-of-an-octave spectra at r = □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m calculated for a train speed of 250 km/h with excitation A. Figure 15.
Train-induced ground vibration on soil 1 (thin layer), third-of-an-octave spectra at r = □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m calculated for the train speeds: (a) 100, (b) 125, b) (c) 160, (d) 200, (e) 250 and (f) 320 km/h, (excitation B). Figure 16.
Train-induced ground vibration on soil 2 (thick layer), third-of-an-octave spectra at r = □ 2.5, ○ 5, Δ 10, + 20, × 30 and ◊ 50 m calculated for the train speeds: (a) 100, (b) 125, (c) 160, (d) 200, (e) 250 and (f) 320 km/h, (excitation B).

More calculated results for both soil models are presented in Figures 15 and 16. The considered train speeds were vT = 100, 125, 160, 200, 250 and 320 km/h and each vibration component can be easily followed in the third‐of‐an‐octave spectra. All results shown in Figures 15 and 16 with excitation B apply to the longer five‐unit train to get a better comparison between the two soil models. The same calculations were performed with excitation A and gave almost the same results. However, it was observed that the mid‐frequency amplitudes were lower at 100 km/h and higher at 320 km/h compared to the amplitudes of excitation B. This will further be analysed in the section ‘The relation between the train speed and the ground vibration amplitudes (amplitude–speed relations)’.

sec.title: Comparison of the calculated spectra with the measurements at sites 1 and 2
sec.p: The calculated results of Figures 15 and 16 can be compared with the results of the measurements given in Figures 12 and 13. The experimental results at site 1 are given for train speeds of 100, 160, 200 and 250 km/h in Figures 12(a) to(d) and can be compared with the theoretical results in Figures 15(a) and (c) to (e). The experimental results of site 2 in Figures 13(a) to (d) are given for train speeds of 180, 200, 250 and 300 km/h which can be compared with the theoretical results in Figures 16(c) to (f) with some minor deviations in train speed.

In general, the measured amplitudes of series 2 are a little higher than those of series 1. One reason is that the train for series 2 is longer (one additional locomotive and car) than for series 1. In addition, the thicker soft layer at site 2 also yields slightly higher amplitudes than the thinner layer at site 1.

All details that are discussed in the preceding sections can be found in the calculated results. The amplitudes of the different low, mid and high-frequency components are very similar to the measured amplitudes. A clear shift of the corresponding frequencies can be observed for all components at measuring site 2. At site 1, this is true for the low and high‐frequency components; however, the mid‐frequency component seems to be almost constant at about 20 to 25 Hz in the measurement as well as in theory. The agreement with the calculated results clearly shows that this strange behaviour can be well explained by the two slightly different soil models. The differences between the two sites are even stronger for the measured speed variations. At site 1, a lower speed range was measured so that the highest speed of 250 km/h just reaches the resonance frequency fL = 25 Hz of the thinner layer. The speed range at site 2 is a rather high‐speed range and that means that all speeds are beyond the resonance frequency fL = 12.5 Hz of the thick layer. Therefore, the mid‐frequency amplitudes of all measured speeds are clearly increasing at site 1 and constant at site 2.

The measurements show more pronounced peaks of the sleeper‐passage excitation at the far‐field points. This means that the Doppler effect is not as strong as for the model; an affect that can be explained in terms of a stronger influence of faster waves such as compression waves or Rayleigh waves through the rock material. The amplitudes of the sleeper‐passage component are somewhat smaller in the measurements which may be a result of the stronger high‐frequency damping of the real soil.

The attenuation of the ground amplitudes with distance follows from the spread of the different curves. At low and high frequencies, a wide band of curves representing a strong attenuation is observed in both experiment and theory. The mid‐frequency curves are close together which means a weak attenuation. This typical shape is found in Figures 12, 13, 15 and 16 in the experimental and theoretical curves, especially clear at lower speeds. The strong low and high‐frequency attenuations make the mid‐frequency component the most important component at the far‐field points.

It can be concluded that a good agreement between calculation and measurement is obtained for the amplitudes and their distribution in frequency and distance for the measuring points in both the near and far fields. This agreement is achieved not only for a single train passage but for a series of different train speeds, and for two different soils at two sites by a unique prediction procedure. Such an extensive comparison is rarely found in the literature.

sec.title: The relation between the train speed and the ground vibration amplitudes (amplitude–speed relations)
sec.p: To get a more detailed quantitative comparison, the amplitudes of certain ground vibration components are evaluated as a function of the train speed. First, the amplitude–speed relations are compared with those from measurements. Then the theoretical methods are used to compare the excitation of the mid‐frequency component by track irregularities and scattered axle impulses.

sec.title: Amplitude–speed relations for the theory and measurements of the different sites
sec.p:
The mid‐frequency amplitudes vM were evaluated for the three dominant thirds of the octaves and the results are presented in Figures 17(a) and (b) in a comparison with the corresponding speed‐dependent amplitudes of the measurements. The measured amplitudes for the train speeds between 180 and 300 km/h closely fit the calculated amplitude–speed relation at site 2 (Figure 17(b)). The measured amplitudes are almost constant (with some scatter) and the smooth theoretical curves are also constant after a minor increase at 100 km/h. The completely different amplitude–speed relations at site 1 are also found in the two measurement series with different trains and amplitude levels (Figure 17(a)). The measured amplitudes continuously increase with the train speeds between 100 and 250 km/h. The wider range of calculated train speeds yields an amplitude–speed relation which also increases up to 250 km/h and has a weaker increase in the amplitude between 250 and 320 km/h. The strong increase up to 250 km/h occurs in both theory and experiment. Figure 17.
Amplitude–speed relations of the mid-frequency component of the ground vibrations at r = 10 m, a) soil 1, calculation with the three-unit train (□) and the four-unit train (Δ) and excitation B, measurement with the three-unit train (▪) and the four-unit train (▴) and (b) soil 2, calculation (○) and measurement (•) with the five-unit train.

The completely different behaviour of the two sites can be easily explained in terms of the different frequencies of the soil layers. For the mid‐frequency component of the ground vibration, the typical excitation frequencies are below, around and above the layer frequencies of the two soils. The layer frequency of site 1 is higher at fL = 25 Hz so that most of the mid‐frequency excitation is below the layer frequency. This means that all results are in the steep rise of the layer cut‐on. The corresponding ground vibration amplitudes are small, but they increase rapidly with increasing train speed. The layer frequency of the thick layer of site 2 is as low as fL = 12.5 Hz. Therefore, the mid‐frequency excitation is above this layer frequency for most of the train speeds. As a result, the ground vibration amplitudes remain almost constant at a high value for site 2.
The observed agreement between the theory and measurements includes the amplitude–speed relations as well as the absolute values of the mid-frequency ground vibrations.

sec.title: Comparison of scattered axle impulses and track irregularities
sec.p:
The amplitude–speed relations of the three dominant thirds of octaves of the mid‐frequency amplitudes are analysed in detail in Figure 18 for the excitation alternatives A and B. Excitation A, the track irregularities, yields increasing amplitudes for both soil models with the increase for soil model 1 being the largest increase. Excitation B, the scattered axle impulses, yields increasing amplitudes for soil model 1, but almost constant amplitudes for soil model 2. The increase with train speed is generally weaker for the scattered impulses than for the track irregularities. This clear difference between track irregularities and scattered‐impulse excitation can be explained by the different speed dependencies of the excitation forces. As shown in Figures 2(b) and 3, the irregularity force increases with vT2 whereas the impulse force is almost constant or slightly decreasing with train speed. The increase of the ground vibration for excitation A (track irregularities) is stronger than the increase in the measurements (Figure 18). The weaker amplitude–speed relations of the axle impulses (excitation B), however, are in good agreement with the measurements. Figure 18.
Amplitude–speed relations of the mid-frequency component of the ground vibrations at r = 10 m, calculated for track alignment irregularities (excitation A) on soil 1 (+) and soil 2 (×) and for scattered axle impulses (excitation B) on soil 1 (□) and soil 2 (○).

A similar observation can be found in Lombaert and Degrande45 where an amplitude–speed relation of A~νT1.25 is predicted for a fixed frequency and for irregularities of s ∼ λ1.25 whereas the measured train‐induced ground vibration seems to be almost constant with train speed.

sec.title: Discussion of the amplitude–speed relations for the other excitation components, for homogeneous soils and from the literature
sec.p:
The amplitude–speed relations are different for all components. The amplitudes of the low‐frequency ground vibration component are analysed in Figure 19 for the measuring point nearest to the track. For all measurements, the low‐frequency amplitude continuously increases with the train speed. The calculated results show the same speed dependency and similar but a little smaller amplitudes. Figure 19.
Amplitude–speed relations of the low-frequency (quasi-static) component of the ground vibrations at r = 2.5 m, soil 1, calculation with the three-unit train (□) and the four-unit train (Δ), soil 2 with the five-unit train (○), first (▪), second (•) and third measurement (▴).

The high‐frequency component of the ground vibration as a function of the train speed is presented in Figure 20. There is no single potential law vH~νTn, however, all theoretical and experimental curves do show an increase, a maximum and a decrease. The maximum is at between 160 and 200 km/h. This specific behaviour has been discussed in detail in the literature.21,22,33 The sleeper‐passage frequency increases with train speed and passes through the vehicle–track resonance frequency at about 200 km/h. Therefore, the amplitudes do not increase at higher train speeds. Moreover, they decrease due to the strong high‐frequency reduction effects of the material damping of the soil. This beneficial high‐speed effect can be clearly found in both theory and experimental data. Figure 20.
Amplitude–speed relations of the high-frequency (sleeper-passage) component of the ground vibrations at r = 5 m, soil 1, calculation with the three-unit train (□) and the four-unit train (Δ), soil 2 with the five-unit train (○), first (▪), second (•) and third measurement (▴).

The total root‐mean‐square values of the ground vibration shown in Figure 21 include all different amplitude–speed relations and the resulting relations are weaker. At the 20 m distance, the mid‐frequency component is dominant and the two corresponding laws, strongly increasing at site 1 and constant at site 2, can be found in a moderate version. Figure 21.
Amplitude–speed relations of all components of the ground vibrations at r = 20 m, a) soil 1, calculation with the three-unit train (□) and the four-unit train (Δ), soil 2 with the five-unit train (○), first (▪), second (•) and third measurement (▴).

The two extreme amplitude–speed relations hold for a specific speed range for a layered soil. The corresponding relation for a homogeneous soil can be written as (15)νM~νT0.5 and it is between the extreme relations (Figure 22). All the amplitude–speed relations were calculated for the short high‐speed passage of the ICE trains which do not fill the time interval. For normally long (quasi‐stationary) train passages, the corresponding amplitude–speed relation would be stronger by the factor vM ∼ vT0.5 which would lead to (16)νM~νT1.0 Figure 22.
Amplitude–speed relations of the mid-frequency component of the ground vibrations at r = 10 m, calculated for scattered axle impulses on soil 1 (thin layer, □), soil 2 (thick layer, ○) and for a homogeneous half-space (+).
for the homogeneous soil.

This proportional relation for the homogeneous soil closely corresponds with many reported amplitude–speed relations.24–28 The presented strong increase at the layer cut‐on closely corresponds with the high exponents in Yoshioka29 and Yokoyama et al.30 which were also evaluated for speed increments at sites consisting of layered soils. The strong increase occurs only for specific layer and train speed conditions and can completely disappear for minor changes of the layering as has been shown for the two closely related measuring sites. In general, the increase in the ground amplitudes weakens for higher speeds due to some conservative effects such as the damping of the soil, passing through the layer resonance and passing through the vehicle–track resonance.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Train‐induced ground vibrations have three typical frequency components, a low‐frequency quasi‐static component which is only important at the very near field, the high‐frequency component due to the sleeper‐passage excitation, and a mid‐frequency component which can be observed at all distances and which is dominant at the far field.

The influence of the train speed on the amplitude of the ground vibration has been analysed. There is no unique amplitude–speed relation for the train-induced ground vibration, not even an approximate one. The relation between amplitude and train speed can be completely different from almost constant to increasing with the fourth power of the train speed. The soil has a dominant influence on the amplitude–speed relation which has been shown for two measuring sites in Germany. The two sites differ only by the depth of the upper layer. A layered soil has a typical strong cut‐on with strongly increasing amplitude with frequency. The amplitude due to train passage is highly dependent on the position of the mid‐frequency component relative to the cut‐on frequency of the layered soil. High and nearly constant amplitudes are observed for different train speeds if the mid‐frequency range is higher than the cut‐on frequency. A strong increase in the amplitude is observed if the mid‐frequency component is just in the range of the strong cut-on phenomenon. These two extreme situations are met at the present measuring sites.

All these components of the train-induced ground vibration as well as the different amplitude–speed relations have been found by the good agreement between a complex theoretical model and a series of measurements. Table 2.
Sleeper-passage frequencies for different train speeds and the frequency band f = fD /(1 ± vT/vS) due to the Doppler effect.
vT (km/h) 100 125 160 200 250 320
fD (Hz) 46 58 74 93 116 148
fMin (Hz) 42 51 64 77 92 111
fMax (Hz) 52 66 89 117 156 221

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
